content: less less get Quincy up here we're so
delighted that we could convince a Quincy lassen to come and speak today
Quincy's been around educating people on the web for a really long time he's one
of the founders of free code camp which is this resource that does incredible
work teaching coding to so many many people this entire community that sprung
up and it's huge and free free code camp is a great example of where the jams
Tech has been applied to great effect so we wanted to try and grab some of that
knowledge grab some of the stories about that from Quincy and share those with
you today so I think I should get out of your way and we should we should welcome
Quincy on the stage so everyone Quincy Lawson everybody thanks Phil hey
everyone I'm just gonna make sure that everything works okay first of all
welcome I hope you all are enjoying the jam STATCOM so far who's enjoying it
raise your hand if you enjoy it yeah all right lots of hands in the air great
so I'm Quincy and I'm gonna talk about how freako camp uses the jam stack to
serve millions of people around the world who are learning to code first I'm
gonna talk about the history of free code camp and our tooling over the years
and how we gradually converged on the jam stack is the way we wanted to do
things then I'm gonna talk a little bit about why we chose the jam stack and
some of the new ways were applying the jam stack so first who here has heard of
free code camp before okay how many people have read like a frico camp
article or watched a video on our YouTube channel how many people have
used the free code camp curriculum itself and the interactive coding
challenges ok quite a few you great so what is free code camp all about we're
all about access we want everybody in the world to be able to learn to code
because we believe everyone in the world should learn to code not just the kids
but the median age of people who are using
freako campus 30 we want people who are anywhere in the world regardless of what
kind of data plan they have what kind of access to electricity they have which is
an issue in a lot of countries we want people who can learn to code on their
hand-me-down phone in Mumbai or people in Auckland who can learn to code at a
public library so we want everything to be browser-based
we want it to be completely self-paced so that you can learn to code even if
you have kids if you have a full-time job if you have a mortgage and a whole
lot of other competing obligations you can still figure out a slice of time
where you can learn to code so making everything browser-based self-paced and
importantly completely free allows the maximum number of people to learn to
code and it makes it possible for everybody to harness these mainframes
that we're carrying around in our pockets and the incredibly inexpensive
computational power that's all around us we want everyone to be able to do that
and to be more productive as a result so I started free code camp back in 2014 I
had this you know it kind of kind of pretentious I think quote but it's from
lousy and I'm a huge I spent a lot of time in China and it was I just wanted
to create a community where people could learn to code and I tinkered with that
for years I worked as a teacher in a school director for about a decade
before I eventually learned to code and the way I did it was purely driven by
necessity I needed to help my my teaching staff be more productive so
they could spend less time chained to their desk doing immigration paperwork
and grade reports and more time actually interacting with with the learners so I
just googled around and figured out how to write Excel macros I figured out how
to use this tool called autohotkey to like programmatically click through
government forms things like that okay I don't hockey
fans great so that was my introduction to coding it and in my 30s
and once I realized what an impact just a little bit of programming capability
had I decided I needed to help as many people learn to code as possible not
just the next generation who are getting you know millions of dollars in funding
from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and things like that but but
working adults who are already mid-career we wanted a resource that
they could use so I iterated for about two years on different adult education
technology products essentially and eventually I simplified everything down
in one very aggressive sprint in my closet office and I got a free coke camp
live after about three days of hard work shoutout to the noun project for this
landing page but I started tweeting it out people started coming people started
hanging out and helping one another and initially we were just using a lot of
existing resources we were using a lot of Stanford courses and mighty courses
and we'd all worked through these together and we just keep each other
motivated and help each other get unstuck in chat and eventually people
started getting jobs and here's a snapshot from our LinkedIn Alumni
Association we've got almost fifty four thousand people people working in IBM
Accenture Tata Amazon Microsoft and Della Google so these people would turn
around and they'd apply the skills they just learned and help improve freako
camp itself so very quickly free code camp went from just being
basically a list of resources to being a full-fledged interactive curriculum and
we became like a legitimate fairly respectful respectable open-source
project and we also had a bunch of people create freako camp study groups
around the world because they wanted to be able to meet in person these were
completely federated in their wasn't really any formal leadership for
me because it was still just me at this point but we had people I'm just gonna
click through them so you can see some of these groups cuz I mean for me it
just blew my mind it still blows my mind these people are getting together often
every week in their City so here's Manchester South Paulo Seoul Guangzhou
Manila bueno Saturdays Vienna Ho Chi Minh City also known as Saigon Mexico
City Sydney Dhaka and at this point like more and more people are using free coke
camp we were getting millions of people coming to free coke camp and we became a
501 C 3 non-profit which was always our goal but it takes a long time to do that
in the United States so we got tax exempt status and people started
donating to us and so we had resources to bring on a full-time team so I I
looked out and I chose for people in the community who had been prolific
contributors who were already doing all this work for free in their free time
and I said come on let's just get you doing this full-time so here here the me
plus these four people these are the people that run free coke games org so
free coke camp at its core is really just a Content community we generate a
whole lot of learning content we're not a technology company we're never going
to be like riding the bleeding edge we don't want to be Facebook and have their
caliber engineering team necessarily we just want stuff that works reliably that
helps people learn to code for free so I'm gonna talk a little bit about the
different types of content we have because that's very important to the jam
stack Jam stack is in my opinion an ideal platform for delivering tons of
content to tons of people so we have our open source curriculum we have which is
powered by the jam stack we have the free code camp guide which I'll talk
about in a minute also powered by the jam stack we have tons of videos
articles podcasts and then we've got our whole portfolio and certification system
so this is the curriculum it's about 1800 hours worth of coding challenges
and I'll just go ahead and show you what one of them looks like if you're curious
in case you haven't checked one out yet so from the landing page does it click
curriculum well make it a little bit bigger you can kind of scroll through
and and see we've got six different certifications we've got the the
html/css certification responsive web design we have a javascript algorithms
and data structures which is just JavaScript you don't have to mess with
any HTML or CSS you're just writing algorithms and getting tests to pass
then we have front-end libraries they covers you know react sass a couple
other popular libraries data visualization a few guys and micro
services and information security and quality assurance so you know we're
covering all the what I view the fundamentals of web development all the
way up to some basic security and testing and then we also have just
thousands of hours of interview prep if anybody's going out and interviewing and
they want to be able to really do well on the coding interviews like whiteboard
coding interviews and stuff you can drill along here so that's the
curriculum and we'll just click through into one of these challenges turn the
image into a link so you can see that the interface is like super simple big
text and and you know you've got the the instructions over here you've got the
coding editor you've got the console for the output and then you've got a preview
of what this HTML and CSS would render and if you scroll down here you can run
the tests and it'll immediately tell you pretty much instantaneously and one of
the reasons this is so fast is it it's all running in the client this is a
static page and you can you know reset your code if you want and you can get a
hint and that'll take you to the guide article you can also watch a video and
pretty proud of this because we just implemented this I talk a lot about free
coke camp being very data light that's very important for us we we have tons of
people in Africa South Asia places that don't necessarily have the best data
plans and the best telecommunication systems in the world you could
definitely argue that the 20% of Americans that don't have broadband
could benefit from this as well so alright so basically it's an or it's a
verbal explanation and you you can see the cursor moving around and you can
this can be refreshed this code can be changed if I go up here and say instead
of click let's say dinglehopper here you know and then I can just resume and I
can refresh this and it should automatically update so this is a cool
tool called Simba and this is not something we personally built but it's
it's our friends in Scandinavia who are building this project and it uses 1/100
of the data that a youtube video with use 1/100 so it's two orders of
magnitude smaller I think if my understanding of how my and if these
work in math is right so it's really cool it just it memorizes
like like it memorizes it it logs like Dom elements in their positions and
stuff like that and then it just has audio track so it it renders all this in
real time so this is things like this the ability to click ask for help and
you go to the forum and we've got like pre-populated template of what you post
in our forum so active that generally people get an answer within less than an
hour even though it's a forum and the assumption is it's asynchronous so we've
the coding environment completely static completely client-side you you go here
and it just loads everything like the first the first time you visit it just
loads everything up and then if you really drill into like some of the later
challenges it may slightly sneak some additional
data in there I'm not gonna open up the network and inspect it but the idea is
that it's static and it immediately works and everything's amazing even if
you have a horrible internet connection and there are a whole lot of other
advantages which I'll talk about a minute but you've been hearing about all
day so we've got the curriculum this is the core free code camps 1800 hours of
coursework you can earn certifications if you complete the five required
projects for each certification you can totally skip everything that's another
thing we want to experience developers to be able to just parachute in and
complete the required projects which all have their own test Suites and
everything you can build them anywhere you can build on your local computer you
can build it on code pen glitch wherever you just pull in our CDN link and you've
got the tests and everything and they'll run against your code and once you get
all the tests passing boom go to free code camp paste in the URL to your
project and you can claim the certification put it on your LinkedIn or
your CV so we've got the certifications then we've got like a portfolio
essentially which is just your activity on free code camp and and we're working
on a way that you can add like a timeline of everywhere you've worked and
gone to school and also additional projects you've done outside of the free
kokyo curriculum our hope is that people don't have to sign up for LinkedIn so
then we have the free code camp guide this is something we just launched like
a year ago completely static 4500 articles served through the jams tag
like with Gatsby so these cover these give you good
enough explanations on pretty much any programming terminology or concepts you
might need you might hear about somebody talking about for example kubernetes one
cubicle over you're like oh my god impostor syndrome kicks in I know
nothing about kubernetes well you can go to free code camps guide and you can
quickly pull up a quick and dirty explanation it's not like Wikipedia
where it's like you know like an academic treatment of the topic with
tons of outbound links and stuff like that no it's just a good enough quick
and dirty explanation of the tool showing some implementation and all this
is open source so people are constantly contributing to these and expanding them
and making them better and so for example freako camp is focused we
have a single monolithic curriculum that focuses on full stack JavaScript but a
lot of people want a Java so we if people have come in and contributed a
ton of articles and tutorials and stuff to our Java section so the the core
curriculum is really the core of free kokum that's what we certify and
everything but we also have a ton of video content here's our YouTube channel
you can see that we just heard a great talk about graphic QL and how amazing it
is we've got a seven and a half hour graph
QL tutorial that we published three weeks ago if you want to watch like a
video tutorial on see it implemented and you may also notice that at the top
there's that code radio with code radio what is it well we have a 24/7 music
stream that plays just jazzy beats and stuff that you can listen to while
you're while you're coding and you can see that about 164 people are watching
right now we have this cool animation loop done by this Colombian artist and
that is based off saran eat of arak the founder of code newbie huge hero of mine
we got our information to put her into a free code camp shirt and put her into
this animation so it's just it's just a cool thing that you can go to if you
want to listen to some music if you want to listen to something other than you
know what your normal Spotify playlist is and then
we have also got you know the YouTube channel thing about YouTube it takes
years and years of hard work to really get the YouTube channel to take off
because YouTube's algorithms are very suspicious at least in our experience so
we finally got it to take off so if you ever create like a video tutorial and
you just want a whole lot of people to see it feel free to like reach out to us
and we may be able to cross post it but you can see there's no ads on our
YouTube channel everything free code camp does is like no ads it's totally
free because we've got amazing donors who support our project then we also
have a bunch of articles this is a thirty three minute tutorial on medium
that talks about kubernetes and how to orchestrate containers this is pretty
typical of the sort of things we publish we publish a lot of in-depth articles on
different tools and technologies and text is a really good format for doing
that because you can have the commands and everything medium is a great place
to publish we are very dependent on medium I one of the things I'm going to
talk about in a minute is just not being so platform dependent on YouTube and
medium but for now you know we've got the biggest medium publication and we
are publishing thousands of articles a year on there so it's a great place if
you write like an article on your blog and you want to cross posted somewhere
where a lot of people see it we've got submissions instructions we've
got a whole team of volunteer editors so both the videos and the articles and the
podcasts are things that we'd like to move over to the jam stack and we have
some ideas for how we would do that and reduce our dependency on you know
YouTube's algorithms and mediums algorithms and so we're working on it
I'm gonna talk a little bit about our tooling over the years so we we grew
very quickly and it was very painful largely because I learned to code in my
30s and I have no formal computer science background I always making
decisions pretty ad-hoc like over here somebody at a hackerspace or meetup oh
why don't you try this okay let's try that and you know you're doing it
production with tons of people using the app and nasty stuff can happen so
version 1 I just put it up on Heroku and I used em lab to host the database and I
use my friend saw hot he had this boilerplate that already had passport
and a lot of the basic user interactions like resetting you know everything so we
use that and we were essentially dynamically rendering static content
because these were just quick articles that explain like go here and do this
and that so I think a lot of people think that they need a web server to run
apps that are largely just content apps just because they need like sessions and
stuff like that I certainly felt that we needed that at the time and like our
Heroku app would like crash and I didn't even know about p.m. to or forever or
any of these libraries and I just be running for meeting the meeting through
San Francisco streets and like I get a text hey free coking its down I'd like
navigate to Heroku and I'd like restart the dyno I did that for like two or
three days before somebody's like why don't you try this this thing that
recovers if you have crashes ah so a lot of downtime version two I thought I was
so smart has anybody heard of second system syndrome okay or also known as
the version to suck in some circles basically you think all those things I
did wrong I'm gonna do I'm gonna fix all of them and what happens you just do it
all over again but you do it usually in a much more costly way so we were like
hey let's just do our own node servers let's do our own MongoDB cluster let's
do our own elasticsearch we thought we're smart we can figure it out and of
course it was expensive as heck things were constantly crashing and I was up
til 3 a.m. looking up Linux commands as a result of
my foolishness so finally Jam stack that is where we
arrived and I'm so grateful to be on the jam stack we now have a single node loop
back web server is basically just our API server and M lab has been kind
enough to give us as an in-kind own like a cluster that we can use our
goalie has given us search and we just use searches way easier to configure
algo Leah and have it reliably work than to deal with the elastic search and then
we're using auth0 for all our authentication and 6,000 plus static
pages serve through net low five CDN so here's how it all works I'll just try to
describe it to the best of my ability so we push code to github and then that
code gets built using Gatsby which is a static site generator Gatsby build it
into a react app then natla Phi serves that react at the end user opens the
browser they open free coke camped out org that static react app that they
pulled from now Fi shows up and then their browser goes ahead and reaches out
to auto and these other API endpoints and figures out off of zero will figure
out if they are if they're authenticated and then it'll give them access to our
API of read and write access so then when they complete challenges and things
like that so data starts getting written through our API to our [ __ ] cluster so
we use the jams tag for a number of reasons first natla Phi's CDN is really
fast and it covers the entire world it even covers you know like they've got a
very specific place for Pakistan and the reason I know that is because we had a
short-term outage no no false of nullifies but basically that was when I
realized like wow how high-resolution their CDN is because it was just a very
few people who were using a very specific mobile carrier that were
affected but those people kept messaging me like crazy and so the the fact that
it's globally distributed he's great and also by choosing this Jam stack
architecture there's very little latency because you know almost all of the
requests are done in the background they get this nice static page all the
contents already there and then just some features are basically unlocked
through time as their browser has time to complete these requests so the fact
that our web servers in Virginia isn't that consequential if they're in
Pakistan okay so the second reason is scaling how many people have ever built
like a web app and then gotten the reddit death hug or producthunt
death hug or hacker news death hug okay so it's it's not pleasant because people
are like oh I can't wait to check out this amazing app that's at the top of
hacker news oh it doesn't work noobs that's what they think right and you're
just sitting there like no everybody's getting like 500 errors and refreshing
repeatedly what just makes things worse so yeah that's one of the reasons why
using jam stacks great because you're relying on other people's really good
infrastructure and you know we offload all the rendering to the clients so we
can have basically nothing in terms of infrastructure another thing that is
really important is simplicity it's so much simpler when you just load the
static pages and you're basically done and their client starts doing everything
else and you know we can use github as a collaboration tool for the content and
just have all the static files on github in markdown I'm just gonna show you what
this looks like so this is our github repository you'll note that there are a
lot of open pull requests apparently after you get 5,000 open pull requests
github just says plus and the reason for that is because we're participating in
October fest again I got my shirt who here's doing Hacksaw professor raise
your hand okay you still have like two days to get five pull requests into free
code camp or any repository that and you just have to make the request you don't
have to have the pull request q8 and merged which otherwise everybody be
screwed because there's no way we're gonna QA 11,000 pull requests by
tomorrow but the way that we're handling this and the reason why so many people
are able to productively contribute to free code camp is we've dramatically
lowered the barriers to entry so for example we
we'll just come here and we'll look at you know the guide and it's just right
here it's like really easy to traverse these directories and know where you
need to go and you can go to let's let's do the Chinese and then we'll just do
agile and then we'll do acceptance testing and we'll look at the file and
here it is this this article on acceptance testing translated into
simplified Chinese so anybody who wants to edit this if they're like oh man he
used this weird word that I would never use I'm just gonna go in here and make
it clear they just click Edit this file and boom they're editing in the markdown
they can preview the changes and then they can go ahead and commit and open up
or request right through github x' interface without even needing to clone
the repo and get it all running locally and everything it just dramatically
reduces the barriers so that's really important for us because we'd like for
free code camp to grow to be as big as Wikipedia at least the technology
related aspects of Wikipedia and the only way we're gonna get there we're not
gonna get there with a five person team we're gonna get there with tens of
thousands of contributors so that that's really like a big thing that we're
working on is just increasing the accessibility of coding and contributing
to open source itself and hex our first great opportunity to do that and have
somebody else pay to ship all the t-shirts so reason number four security
when your app is super simple it just means there are fewer things that can go
wrong fewer things to keep track of your attack surfaces we have a single API
that we need to safeguard its I don't lose sleep over security like I used to
when we had all our own infrastructure so some ways we're going to use the jam
stack we're going to finish the internationalization process if you know
we've already translated into Arabic Chinese Russian Portuguese Spanish those
languages plus English that's like three-quarters of the Earth's population
can now learn on free code camp in their native language that really reduces the
barriers and increases the access we're also trying to
reduce our dependence on on platforms like YouTube and medium by having our
own free coke amp news and I've been publishing on free coke amp news myself
for a while but we're gonna open it up to where anybody in the community can
cross post from their blogs places like that and then our editor team can go in
and say hey this is a really great article or this is a really great
podcast episode whatever the content happens to be that they post it and they
can basically bump that up to the top so everybody on free coke camp that org can
see that and be like oh let's check this out so it's kind of like an editorial
like human curated newsfeed and then really like jam stack set you up pretty
nicely for doing an offline app because you know static files you can
potentially load those onto a Raspberry Pi you can load a lot of the
functionality and our dream is to get free code camp and a whole lot of other
creative commons content and open source content put it on a raspberry pi's and
just ship it to schools in the developing world so that people who
don't necessarily have access to you know stable electricity they have
periodic outages throughout the day can just load it up we also have people and
you know people who can't get internet access we have a number of Prisons in
the United States that use free code camp is there curricula and so inmates
learn free code camp they don't have the right to get on the internet but they
can still learn to code using free code camp so right now they're doing that on
a local area network if we get these on raspberry PI's it'll be way easier for
those people to learn skills so when they get out they'll be able to have a
productive career and have marketable skills so there are a number of things
that we're doing that are related to the jam stack we're super jazzed about the
jam stack as I could tell pretty much everybody here is certainly all the
people up on stage so I would definitely encourage you all if you're interested
in participating in the October fest you still have a couple days left if you
have questions about how you can contribute your skills and your talents
to the free code camp community and help millions of people around the world
learn to code just DM me on Twitter I've got open VMs and enjoy jam stack Oh
